div.p:
I Have real ≈øomewhere of an Hermite, who being guided by an Angel unto two Cities, ≈øaw the Gates of the fir≈øt clo≈øe ≈øhut, and a Devil having the Keys thereof at his Girdle in a deep ≈øleep, and ≈ønorting, From thence he is led unto the other, (which was fair and ≈øpacious,) and finds the Gates wide open, innumerable Devils crouding and thronging in, multitudes climbing over the walls, and whole ≈øwarms of them in the Churches, Streets, Hou≈øes, Shops, walks, and all other Avenues
and places of concour≈øe, exceedingly employed, bu≈øying and be≈øtirring them≈øelves to the utmo≈øt for the ruine of it, and her Inhabitants. At which wondring beyond mea≈øure, the Angel told him, yonder City is the wor≈øt of the Two, ingulpht in all wickedne≈øs and irreligion, ≈øo that Beelzebub hath no fear of loo≈øing it, and therefore there is but one Devil to guard it, and his work ≈øo little, that he ≈øleeps. But as for this wherein now we are, here are many Souls fearing and ≈øerving God, Religion is profe≈ø≈øed, and Religious Wor≈øhip countenanced and incouraged, and the Holy Angels of God are watching over the≈øe precious Saints and their Habitations to pre≈øerve them. This hath cau≈øed Hell to break loo≈øe, and to endeavor by all means, and arts imaginable their ruine, and its de≈øtruction.

Sirs, I think this be no unfitting Emblem of our Plymouth, wherein I tru≈øt there are multitudes of Gods dear Servants, as well as Sinners: But I fear me, multitude of Devils al≈øo, that walk in
Temples and Congregations, in Streets and Hou≈øes, in Chambers and Clo≈øets, in Ships and Shops, upon Keys and Exchange. The over abounding of Sin among us, and of late of that hainous and crying ≈øin of Blood and Murther, (for which Two of the prime Actors (and God knows whether there be any other) have ≈øuffered condign puni≈øhment,) is too ≈øad and clear an in≈øtance hereof. When Hannibal was at the Gates of Rome, it was more than time for the Con≈øuls and Senate to look about them. Woe! Woe! Unto the Inhabitants of the Earth, ≈øaith an Angel from Heaven, Becau≈øe the Devil is come down among you, having great wrath, for his time is ≈øhort. He doth not appear in a vi≈øible ≈øhape at noon day, but walks (as his younger Son the Je≈øuite) in all ≈øorts of Ma≈øques and di≈øgui≈øes, in every habit and fa≈øhion, and among Per≈øons of every Trade, Calling, Quality, and Condition.

Now, Sirs, God having con≈øtituted you the Angel-Guardians of our Plymouth,
and made you Gods unto it, there is all rea≈øon you ≈øhould be awake, and do your utmo≈øt to prevent the Stratagems and attempts of Hell again≈øt it. I know no other way or means that you have, than by an exemplary Holine≈øs in your lives, than by walking with God in your re≈øpective Families and Callings, than by a couragious, zealous, activity for God and Godline≈øs, and a vigorous ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion, and impartial puni≈øhing of all Vice and Impiety. Would you but continue your great re≈øpects and incouragements to your Reverend and Learned Mini≈øters, and joyn both Swords together, Temporal and Spiritual, I am confident the de≈øigns of Hell again≈øt you would be broken, fru≈øtrated, and rendered ineffectual.

Honored Sirs, My hearts de≈øire and Prayer for you is, that you may do worthily in your Ephrata, and Famou≈øly in your Bethlehem, that you may glorifie God in your Station, and that God may reflect rays and beams of Glory upon you, For ≈øuch as Honor him, God
will Honor them, but they that de≈øpi≈øe him ≈øhall be lightly e≈øteemed, 1 Sam. 2.30.

Sirs, if you will ≈øuppre≈øs all prophanene≈øs, and by your Authority put out the Fire of uncleanne≈øs, if you will ≈øtop the Mouth, and Gag the Tongue of the Swearer, that the Roaring of Oaths and Cur≈øes be not heard in our Streets, if you will promote true practical Piety, and per≈øevere as you have begun in the con≈øcientious di≈øcharge of your Magi≈øtratical Duty, the God of ble≈ø≈øings will ble≈øs your per≈øons and Families, and Plymouth ≈øhall never be a Sodom but Zion, ≈øhall ever be a, Jeru≈øalem for Go≈øpel-priviledges, a Pillar and Ground of Truth, rich and flouri≈øhing as Tyre for Trade and Traffick, and as formerly, ≈øo in after-times a Zoar for Divine ≈øafety and wonderful pre≈øervations.

That endeared affection I have for the Town of my Nativity, where I fir≈øt drew my breath, and where I had my School-Education, moveth me to ≈øpeak
and write ≈øo freely. And your true goodne≈øs cannot but make a candid interpretation thereof.

May Plymouth, her Magistrates and Government ever live before God! May this Famous Town be called Hephzibah and Beulah, the Delight of God, and Married unto God! Let her be called the Righteous, the Holy City! And may this be her name unto Po≈øterity, Jehovah Shamma, The Lord is there. So prayeth, Right Honored Sirs.

div.head: THE PREFACE
div.p: THe Devil is ≈øtiled by our ble≈ø≈øed Saviour. A Murderer from the beginning; Having de≈øtroyed him≈øelf by his willful A po≈øtacy from God, and being ju≈øtly bani≈øhed the Glories of the cele≈øtial Paradi≈øe for his Voluntary Rebellion, he turned about him, ≈øeeking how and in what manner he might be revenged on his Judg. And after all his rueful thoughts and con≈øultations could find no expedient more likely to ≈øucceed and take than the working mi≈øchief on mankind.

Our fir≈øt Parents a Compendium of both Worlds, Sublunary and Aetherial, the Crown of Gods Creation, but a little lower than the Angels, are become the objects of his rage and fury. Satan had lo≈øt Heaven, and he envies them Earth. Their habitation in an Earthly Heaven di≈øplea≈øeth him, becau≈øe it plea≈øeth God. They ju≈øt now came out of their Creators hands endowed with a double Portion, Holyne≈øs and happine≈øs: But he re≈øolves they ≈øhall not long enjoy either. Hence in the very fir≈øt dawn of their Creation, he contrived and accompli≈øhed their de≈øtruction. He ≈øubtilly in≈øinuates the poy≈øon of ≈øin by his conferences with, and ≈øugge≈øtions unto Eve, and ≈øhe having once ta≈øted of the do≈øe, and allured with the deceitful plea≈øantne≈øs thereof to her ≈øen≈øual appetite, communicates it to her Husband, and they both derive it down unto all their natural po≈øterity.

Ah! How many Murders were in this One? Mankind made and ruined altogether. Certainly they who plotted the blowing up of King and Kingdom in One hour, they who effected the Sicilian Ve≈øpers,
Pari≈øian Mattins, and Iri≈øh Ma≈ø≈øacres had been all trained up and Educated in the Schools of this, this old, and Grand Abaddon.

Adam being in Honor, continued not a day in it. His glorious ≈øtate did ≈øhine, and ≈øet with the ≈øame Sun. In the Morning it flouri≈øhed and grew up, in the Evening it was cut down and withered like the Gra≈øs. He played away (as a be≈øorted Game≈øter) his whole, and all pre≈øent and to come, what he had in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, what he might have in Rever≈øion, at one ca≈øt. Nothing was left him but his ≈øin and cur≈øe, and this he propagates unto all his Children. (A mo≈øt ≈øad Portion) to be inherited by us.

Sin being now conceived doth prodigiou≈øly ≈øpawa and ≈øwarm. The Old Serpent is not idle. His boiling malice gives him no re≈øt. His fir≈øt born like the Plague ≈øpreads its venom univer≈øally, and new Mon≈øters are hatched and produced by it every day. New ≈øins in new ≈øhapes, in odious and hideous colours ≈øhew forth their heads. Grace is mode≈øt. Sin impudent and ≈øhamele≈øs: It ≈øeeketh no di≈øgui≈øe, nor putteth on a Vizard, but for its own ≈øecurity, and in order to further mi≈øchief, to perpetrate ≈øome greater Villany.

The Devil having ≈øet variance between God and Man, will give another ca≈øt of his Office: He throws a Bone of contention between Man and Man. The neare≈øt Relations, the deare≈øt Friends, they that had the ≈øame fle≈øh in their Bodies, the ≈øame blood in their veins, that if not Twins yet ≈øcarce divided in their age, that were Nur≈øt, Fed, and Educated together, both alike tendered by their Indulgent and Religious Parents, ≈øhall yet through his ≈øubtilty and cruelty be ≈øundered and divided one from the other: And if he cannot drag them both with him≈øelf into Hell, yet will he precipitate
the one by a bloody and Barbarous death into his untimely Grave, and the other (by a ≈øin like his own) into the bottomle≈øs Pit of de≈øtruction ere he is aware of it.

Cain by the in≈øtigation of the wicked one, upon no provocation, no offence given, (unle≈øs Gods gracious acceptance of Abel for his Faith and Holine≈øs be a crime,) Murthers his own, his only and deare≈øt Brother. Bloody Villain! Thou choppe≈øt off thy right hand with thy left, thou da≈øhe≈øt out thine own Brains in da≈øhing out his. Thou de≈øtroye≈øt his, body, but damne≈øt thine own Soul. Ah, what grief it this to Pious Adam! Oh, what joy and Mu≈øick unto Hell! Revenge is ≈øweet. But its a poor revenge, Satan! Which ends hi thine own, in thine endle≈øs de≈øtruction.

However the Devil hath ≈øhown the way of Murthering, and bad Arts are ≈øoon learnt. Any one may be an ea≈øie and early proficient in Ungodline≈øs, the whole and old World ≈øoon got the skill of it. God ≈øaw that the wickedne≈øs of man was great in the earth, and that every imagination of the thoughts of his heart was only evil continually. The Earth al≈øo was corrupt before God, and filled with Violence: All fle≈øh had perverted its way, and blood touched blood.

There was no fair and gentle means left une≈ø≈øayed by God to reclaim ≈øinners, to dam up, if po≈ø≈øible, the torrents of their ungodline≈øs, to ≈øtench tho≈øe foul i≈ø≈øues, and frequent effu≈øions of Innocent blood. Adam, and the Holy Patriarks decry it down in their Lives and Sermons. Enoch (the Phoenix of his Age for the life and power of Godline≈øs ≈øhining mo≈øt illu≈øtriou≈øly in his Conver≈øation) Thunders out Prophe≈øies of dreadful Judgments again≈øt the irreligious Cainites. Behold, ≈øaith that Glorious
Saint, The Lord cometh with Holy Myriads of Angels to Execute vengeance upon all the ungodly, and to convince you of your ungodline≈øs in flames of Fire, who will not be convinced by our Mini≈øtry. Upon the wicked he ≈øhall Rain Snares, Fire, and Brim≈øtone, and an horrible Tempe≈øt, This ≈øhall be the Portion of their Cup.

But the Prophet is counted a Fool, and the Spiritual man Mad, and his Menaces of approaching wrath idle Dreams, melancholly thoughts, bugbears to fright Children, and bublings up of his envy and malice again≈øt them. Thus he and his Prophecies are de≈øpi≈øed, and ≈øcornfully rejected.

At la≈øt fair warning and loud calls and Summons unto Repentance having been long afforded them, and not accepted, nor in the lea≈øt improved, the patience of God is tired, mercy finally departs from them, and Divine Ju≈øtice ≈øweeps away the Habitations and per≈øons of tho≈øe Scarlet Sinners with a deluge of Waters.

One would have thought that ≈øuch a fearful Judgment ≈øhould have cautioned afterages from ever treading in their ≈øteps. But alas! Po≈øterity is grown ≈øtupid, and Judgment-proof. As for Gods Judgments the wicked makes a puff at them, they are afar off, above, and out of his ≈øight, he forgets and makes no reckoning, nor account of them. God hath Hanged up ≈øome in Chains before their eyes, Executed a whole World of Malefactors, and made them an everla≈øting Sign and Example to them, yet they willfully ≈øhut their eyes that they may not ≈øee, and lock up the Doors of their hearts, that they may not con≈øider for what cau≈øes this great wrath is come upon them. So that we need not wonder at Gods plaguing ≈øuch willful blind Souls. It is but a righteous Retribution that his Ju≈øtice oweth them. In as much as they
regarded not the works of the Lord, nor took notice of the operation of his hand, he could not build them up, he mu≈øt totally and utterly de≈øtroy them. Sinners ate the Voluntary Carvers of their own misfortunes. They choo≈øe and Create unto them≈øelves their own bane and de≈øtruction, Temporal and Eternal. The reading of this en≈øuing Narrative will be a clear proof and evidence hereof.

div.p: THe ≈øaid Informant ≈øaith, that on Munday la≈øt, being the three and twentieth day of this in≈øtant Augu≈øt, about Nine of the Clock in the Evening, he being ≈øent for to come to the Hou≈øe of William Weeks of this Town Dyer; This Informant was by the people of the Hou≈øe informed concerning the death of the ≈øaid Ma≈øter Weeks his Wife, who told him that ≈øhe was taken with Vomiting, Scouring and Purging, and ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid William Weeks Dyer, being a Bed Sick, he asked him how he did, who told him, that he had a great pain in his Stomack, and that he was ≈øwollen in his Stomack, and what≈øoever he did take, he did Vomit it up again; And this Informant further ≈øaith, that he going into a Chamber to ≈øee Mi≈øtris Mary Pengelley; who told this informant, that ≈øhe had a very great pain in her Stomack, and was ≈øwollen, and that ≈øhe was taken with violent Purging and Vomiting, and cold Sweats, and Faintings, with great drought; And this Informant being ≈øo informed, he judged that there was Poy≈øon in the Ca≈øe, and thereupon de≈øired to make an inquiry concerning it; And this Informant farther ≈øaith, that ye≈øterday in the Morning, one Mi≈øtris Hurd bringing to him ≈øomething which ≈øhe had taken out of ≈øome of the Girts, which was put in the Portage; This Informant judged it to be Poy≈øon.

div.head: The Information of Mary the Wife of James Hurd of Plymouth Merchant, taken as afore≈øaid on Oath.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid Informant ≈øaith, that ≈øhe was ≈øent for to come to the Hou≈øe of William Weeks Dyer, on Sunday la≈øt pa≈øt, and when this Informant came to the ≈øaid Hou≈øe, ≈øhe met with Mi≈øtris Pengelley, who told her that ≈øhe was very Sick, and that her Father and Mother were al≈øo very Sick, that they were a Bed a≈øleep. This Informant departed, and came again the next Morning, and this Informant then meeting with the ≈øaid Mi≈øtris Pengelley, ≈øhe asked her how her Father and Mother did, who told her that they were very ill, and de≈øired this Informant to go up in the Chamber and ≈øee them: And when this Informant came into the Chamber, ≈øhe found the ≈øaid Ma≈øter Weeks his Wife very ill, with Vomiting and Purging; and ≈øhe demanded of them what they had eaten the day before: They ≈øaid, nothing but Pottage; And this Informant further ≈øaith, that ≈øhe coming into the Court of the ≈øaid Ma≈øter Weekes, ≈øhe ≈øaw Vomiting there which the Dog had done, whereupon ≈øhe de≈øired them to take ≈øome Oyl and Sack, which was taken by Ma≈øter Weeks and his Daughter Pengelley, but his Wife did take very little, and that the Nur≈øe and Child took ≈øome Sack and Oyl likewi≈øe. And this Examinant further ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid Mi≈øtris Weeks continued ≈øo bad till about Three of the Clock in the Afternoon, and then died: And endeavoring to find out the cau≈øe, the next day they put a Spoonful of the ≈øameOatmeal. Girts which were in the Pottage, and boyled it in a Pint of Water, and gave the ≈øame to the Dog. And about half an hour after, the Dog was taken with Vomitings, and looking into the bottom of the Skillet wherein the
Water and Girts were boyled, took out ≈øome Yellow thing, which they under≈øtood to be Yellow Ar≈øenick; to make a further di≈øovery, they took the remainder of theOatmeal. Girts, and put them in a Bowl of Water, intending to ≈øee what was therein, to ≈øtand a little white, and when they came to ≈øee for it, theOatmeal. Girts were taken out, and the Water thrown away by Anne Evans (Apprentice to the ≈øaid William Weeks Dyer) into the Sink; and ≈øeeing afterwards into the Sink, they took up ≈øome more of the Poy≈øon, and ≈øhewed it to Doctor Holland, and ≈øome other Phy≈øitians, who ≈øaid it was Yellow Ar≈øenick.

div.head: The Information of Hugh Littleworth, taken before the Right Wor≈øhipful William Weeks Major of Plymouth. Augu≈øt 25. 1675.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid Informant faith, that he having ≈øome di≈øcour≈øe with Anne Evans, ≈øhe ≈øaid, that there had been a difference between the Nur≈øe Philip Wife of Richard Cary and her Mi≈øtris Weeks, and the ≈øaid Philip Cary ≈øaid, that ≈øhe would fit her Mi≈øtris, and the ≈øaid Philip Cary asking of the ≈øaid Evans where ≈øhe ≈øhould have any Rats-bane. Who replied, if ≈øhe did go to the Apothecary, he would take her name. And al≈øo the ≈øaid Evans confe≈ø≈øed to this Informant, that ≈øhe gathering of Herbs on Wedne≈øday or Thur≈øday la≈øt in the Garden, ≈øome Stones were thrown in over the Wall into the Garden, and at la≈øt a Paper was thrown in, which ≈øhe took up and carried it in, and put it in a Salt-Sellar, ≈øhewing it to the ≈øaid Philip Cary, who told her that ≈øhe did not know what it was, and then
≈øhe put it into the Salt-Sellar again, and ≈øeeking for it on Sabbath day at night, it was gone out of the Salt-Sellar. And this Informant further ≈øaith, that he was informed by Chri≈øtopher Scibbow, that the ≈øaid Philip Cary was packing up her Cloaths to be gon.

postscript.p: Elizabeth Crone and Anne Partridge both depo≈øe the ≈øame.

div.head: The Information of the ≈øaid Philip Cary taken as afore≈øaid.
div.p: THe ≈øaid Informant ≈øaith, that on Munday was Sevennight, there was a difference between her and her Mi≈øtris concerning the Frying of Pilchards, and among≈øt other things, the ≈øaid Mi≈øtris Weeks called this Informant Whore, and ≈øaid, that ≈øhe was her Husbands Whore. And this Informant told the ≈øaid Mi≈øtris Weeks, that ≈øhe had made a difference between this Informant and her Husband; but the next Morning the ≈øaid Mi≈øtris Weeks and this Informant were very good Friends; and this Informant going to call her Husband where he was at Keels, he took up a Bowl in his Hand, and ≈øaid, that ≈øhe ≈øhould go home to Ma≈øter Weeks, for that ≈øhe was his Whore. And this Informant further ≈øaith, that this Informant and her Husband being invited to Dinner to the ≈øaid Ma≈øter Weeks his Hou≈øe on Sabbath day la≈øt, and when ≈øhe came, there was a Di≈øh of Pottage laded up before ≈øhe came, which ≈øhe did eat, and her Husband did eat two Di≈øhes of the ≈øame Pottage.

And this Informant further ≈øaith, that Mi≈øtris Pengelley did tell this Informant, that Anne Evans did
ri≈øe on Sabbath day by Four of the Clock in the Morning, which ≈øhe did wonder at, and this Informant further ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid Anne Evans told her, that ≈øhe would go away with the Mountebanks, for ≈øhe could not indure the hardne≈øs of her Mi≈øtris.

And this Informant further ≈øaith, that the Munday following, ≈øhe Vomited and Purged, and that ≈øhe had great pains in her Stomack, and Griping in the Guts, and al≈øo ≈øaith, that there are no retainers belonging to the Hou≈øe be≈øides this Informant, and the ≈øaid Anne Evans, and that no one el≈øe doth dre≈øs the Meat.

div.head: The Examination of Anne Evans, taken as afore≈øaid on Oath the 26th. of Augu≈øt, 1675.
div.p: THe ≈øaid Examinant ≈øaith, that about a Fourtnight or Three Weeks ≈øince, there then being a difference between her Mi≈øtris Elizabeth Weeks, and Nur≈øe Philip Cary, the ≈øaid Nur≈øe ≈øaid, that ≈øhe would fit her one way or other. And this Informant further ≈øaith, that a Tue≈øday la≈øt, ≈øhe going out into the Garden to gather Herbs, among≈øt the Mary golds ≈øhe found a Paper, in which was a yellow Stone, which ≈øhe thought was Painting, but now ≈øhe ≈øuppo≈øeth it was Rats-bane, ≈øo this Informant carried it in, and put it in a Salt-Sellar, and a Saturday ≈øhe ≈øhewed the ≈øame to the Nur≈øe, and asked her what it was, who told her ≈øhe knew not, and then ≈øhe put it in the Salt. Sellar again.

And this Examinant further ≈øaith, that the next day after the ≈øaid difference, the ≈øaid Nur≈øe told this Examinant, ≈øhe did wi≈øh the old Gyp≈øon were ≈øo far as ≈øhe did wi≈øh her, and ≈øaid that ≈øhe would fit her, and this Examinant asking her how, ≈øhe an≈øwered, a little
Rats-bane would make work with her by and by. And this Examinant asking her where ≈øhe would have it, ≈øhe ≈øaid that there was enough at the Apothecaries. And this Examinant told her, that he would take her name, and ≈øhe an≈øwered, that there was an Apothecary in St. Andrews Street that did not know her.

And this Examinant further ≈øaith, that on Saturday la≈øt, this Examinant fetched a Pot of Beer for her Ma≈øter before he went to Plympton, and her Ma≈øter made a Toa≈øt, and put in Nutmeg and Sugar therein, and did Drink thereof, and her Mi≈øtris, and Mi≈øtris Pengelley, and her Son John, and put the remainder in the Window, and when this Examinant came to ≈øee for the Drink, there was a great Spider in it, then ≈øhe took out the Spider with a Spoon, and left in the Window, and a little after ≈øhe asking the Nur≈øe whether ≈øhe had drank the Beer that ≈øtood in the Window, ≈øhe ≈øaid no. Then this Examinant told her that there was a Spider in it, but ≈øhe had taken it out, and did believe that her Mi≈øtris had drank it; then the Nur≈øe replied, thou ≈øhoulde≈øt have let it alone thou Fool, and not have taken it out, but ≈øhoulde≈øt have ≈øquatted it abroad in the Beer.

closer.signed: The Sign of Anne A.E. Evans.

div.head: The Examination of the ≈øaid Philip Cary, taken as afore≈øaid.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid Examinant being demanded whether ≈øhe did ≈øay that ≈øhe did wi≈øh the old Gyp≈øon were ≈øo far as ≈øhe did wi≈øh, and that ≈øhe would fit her, and whether ≈øhe did ≈øay that her Rats-bane would work with her by and by, of words to that effect, ≈øhe an≈øwered, no. And being demanded whether ≈øhe had
any di≈øcour≈øe with the ≈øaid Anne Evans touching the Spider on Saturday la≈øt, which ≈øhould be taken out of the Beer, ≈øhe ≈øaith ≈øhe had; and being demanded why ≈øhe ≈øaid to the ≈øaid Evans, that ≈øhe ≈øhould have let the Spider alone and ≈øquatted it abroad in the Beer, or u≈øed any words to that effect, ≈øhe ≈øaith, that ≈øhe had no di≈øcour≈øe with her, nor ≈øpake any ≈øuch thing; and this Examinant further ≈øaith, that ≈øhe did hear the ≈øaid Anne Evans ≈øay, that ≈øhe would make away with her Mi≈øtris, to wit, the ≈øaid Mi≈øtris Weeks, there being a difference between them on Saturday was Fourtnight, to the be≈øt of this Examinants remembrance: and being demanded why ≈øhe did not reveal it, ≈øhe an≈øwered, that the ≈øaid Anne Evans did de≈øire her that ≈øhe would not reveal it, for if ≈øhe did, ≈øhe ≈øhould be even killed, and therefore ≈øhe did forbear to reveal it.

closer.signed: The Sign of the ≈øaid Philip Cary.

div.head: The Examination of Anne Evans, taken before the Right Wor≈øhipful. William Weeks Major, and William Jennings Merchant, two Ju≈øtices, &c. the Fir≈øt day of September 1675.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid Examinant ≈øaith, that there hath been a continual difference between the ≈øaid Nur≈øe Philip Cary, and her Mi≈øtris Elizabeth Weeks, and the ≈øaid Philip Cary did ≈øay ≈øeveral times, that ≈øhe would fit the ≈øaid Mi≈øtris Weeks. And this Examinant further ≈øaith, that ye≈øterday was Fourtnight, ≈øhe being in the Herb Garden, there were ≈øome Stones thrown into the Herb Garden by ≈øome Children which were out in the Lane, and ≈øhe looking out over the Wall, ≈øaw the ≈øaid Philip Cary and the Child out in the Lane. And this Examinant further ≈øaith, that ≈øhe
then took up a Paper, in which was a yellow Stone, which ≈øhe thought was yellow Painting, but now ≈øhe doth think that it was Rats-bane, ≈øo this Examinant carried it in, and put it in a Salt-Sellar, and the Saturday following, this Examinant clean≈øing of the Shelves, ≈øhe took it down, and put it in her Pocket, and in the Evening ≈øhe ≈øhewed it to the Nur≈øe, and asked her what it was, who ≈øeeming not to take notice of it, ≈øhe (this Examinant) put it again in the Salt-Sellar, ≈øo ≈øhe went out unto the Conduit to fetch ≈øome Water, and when ≈øhe came in again, this Examinant further ≈øaith, that ≈øhe doth believe, that the ≈øaid Nur≈øe did take down the ≈øaid Rats-bane, for that when ≈øhe came in, ≈øhe ≈øaw the ≈øaid Nur≈øe breaking of it between two Tiles into Powder, and this Examinant asking her what ≈øhe would do with it when ≈øhe had broken it, ≈øhe replied, ≈øhe was going to fit a Medicine for the old Woman, meaning the ≈øaid Mi≈øtris Weeks, and then the ≈øaid Nur≈øe, when ≈øhe had broken the ≈øame ≈ømall, ≈øhe took ≈øome of the ≈øame Rats bane and put it in a Cloam-Di≈øh, and then drew about a quarter of a Pint of Small Beer to it, and ≈øo let it ≈øteep all night long: And then the ≈øaid Nur≈øe gave ≈øome of the ≈øaid Rats-bane to this Informant, and told her that ≈øhe ≈øhould put the ≈øame into the Old womans Di≈øh, when ≈øhe did take up ≈øome Pottage for her, and you ≈øhall ≈øee, as ≈øhe ≈øaid, what ≈øport we ≈øhall have with her to Morrow, and that which this Examinant ≈øhould give her, would do her no hurt, but that which ≈øhe had fitted would do her work, and that it would make her die within half an hour, and ≈øaid, when the Old woman was gone, that we ≈øhould live ≈øo merry as the days were long. And this Examinant further ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid Nur≈øe did charge this Examinant upon her life, that ≈øhe ≈øhould not tell of it, for unle≈øs that ≈øhe this Examinant did not declare it, it would never
come to light: And withal, told this Examinant, that if ≈øhe did tell of it, ≈øhe would deny it, and lay it all upon this Examinant. And this Examinant further ≈øaith, that the next day being Sunday, having Boiled a piece of Beef, and part of a Neck of Veal and Cabbidge, and Carrots, and made Pottage; And then about Eleven of the Clock, the ≈øaid Mi≈øtris Weeks asked for a Di≈øh of Pottage, and bid this Examinant lade up a Di≈øh, which this Examinant did, and then put in the ≈øaid Rats-bane into the Di≈øh, according as the Nur≈øe had ordered, thinking of no hurt; and this Examinant ≈øaith, that the ≈øaid Mi≈øtris Weeks did eat up all the Pottage, and left the Bread in the Di≈øh, and then ≈øhe laded up more Pottage to the Bread in the ≈øame Di≈øh, and the ≈øaid Ma≈øter Weeks did eat up all the Pottage, and very little Bread: and then Mi≈øtris Marry Pengelley laded up ≈øome more Pottage to the ≈øame Bread, in the ≈øame Di≈øh, which ≈øhe did then eat up all, Pottage and Bread. And this Examinant ≈øaith, that about three hours after the ≈øaid Mi≈øtris Weeks was taken with Purging and Vomiting, and being very dry, they gave this Examinant order to fetch a Pot of Strong Beer in a Silver Tankard, and the mean while the ≈øaid Nur≈øe made a To≈øt to put in it, which ≈øhe accordingly fetcht, and when ≈øhe came into the Kitchin, where the ≈øaid Nur≈øe was making of a Toa≈øt, ≈øhe gave the Tankard with the Beer unto the Nur≈øe: And this Examinant ≈øaith, that ≈øhe did ≈øee the ≈øaid Nur≈øe Drink a little of the Beer, which was in the ≈øaid Tankard, and then pre≈øently filled it up again with the ≈øame Beer, in which the ≈øaid Rats-bane was ≈øteeped in the night before, and then the ≈øaid Nur≈øe carried the ≈øame Beer up in the Chamber unto the ≈øaid Ma≈øter Weeks and Mi≈øtris Weeks: And this Examinant going up after her with a Swab to take up the Vomiting. This Examinant ≈øaw the ≈øaid Mi≈øtris Weeks
Drink fir≈øt of the ≈øaid Beer, and then ≈øhe delivered it to Ma≈øter Weeks, and he did Drink, ≈øo he delivered it to Mi≈øtris Pengelley, and ≈øhe found fault with it, and ≈øaid, that the Beer was keamy, and that if they had no better, they ≈øhould fetch it at ≈øome other place. But this Examinant did ≈øee the ≈øaid Mi≈øtris Pengelley eat ≈øome of the ≈øaid Toa≈øt: And this Examinant further ≈øaith, having the next day an occa≈øion to make u≈øe of the ≈øaid Tankard, found the in≈øide thereof in the bottom, black, yellow, and di≈øcolored, as though it was Cankered, and the Nur≈øe bad her Scour it out with Sand, whereas before when ≈øhe fetcht the Beer it was clean.

And this Examinant further ≈øaith, that ≈øhe being troubled to ≈øee her Ma≈øter and Mi≈øtris ≈øo Sick; ≈øhe ≈øaid, Alas! Nur≈øe, what have you done, that our Ma≈øter and Mi≈øtris are ≈øo very Sick? She replied, what ≈øhe had done as to Mi≈øtris Weeks, ≈øhe had done God good Service in it, to rid her out of the way, and hoped that ≈øhe had done her bu≈øine≈øs, and did look upon it, that ≈øhe had done no ≈øin in it; and ≈øaith, as to the Girts that ≈øhe can ≈øay no farther, but what ≈øhe hath ≈øaid in her former Examination; to which for more certainty ≈øhe referreth her ≈øelf.

closer.signed: The Mark of the ≈øaid Anne A. E. Evans.

div.head: The Examination of the ≈øaid Philip Cary, taken as afore≈øaid.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid Examinant being demanded whether the ≈øaid Anne Evans did not ≈øhow her the ≈øaid yellow Stone, on Saturday la≈øt was Sevennight, and whether ≈øhe did not break it abroad in Powder between two Tiles, and whether ≈øhe did not ≈øteep part of it in a Di≈øh in
Small Beer, and whether ≈øhe did not give ≈øome of the ≈øame Rats-bane which ≈øhe had broken unto the ≈øaid Anne Evans, and told her that ≈øhe ≈øhould put it into the Old womans Di≈øh, meaning the Old Mi≈øtris Weeks, or u≈øed any words to that effect, an≈øwered, No. And being demanded al≈øo, whether ≈øhe had any dicour≈øe with the ≈øaid Anne Evans, concerning the Poy≈øon mentioned in the afore≈øaid Examination of the ≈øaid Anne Evans, or any words to that effect, denies the ≈øame; but ≈øaith, that ≈øhe doth believe that they ≈øhall both die for it, becau≈øe ≈øhe hath concealed the Coun≈øel of the ≈øaid Anne Evans.

ANd now they are in ≈øafe Cu≈øtody, in the Pri≈øon joyning to the Town-Hall in Plymouth, where they have time and lei≈øure to ruminate upon their foul and odious Crime, to con≈øider of the horrible danger to which the≈øe pretious Souls are expo≈øed, and to make their Peace with God, if it be well husbanded and improved. But I fear me, that though the Lord wait graciou≈øly Six Months together for their Repentance, and cry aloud by this terrible di≈øpen≈øation to convert, reform and give Glory to him before they come to Judgment, we ≈øhall even after their Condemnation at the A≈ø≈øizes, meet with other and wor≈øe news from them. Before we talk with the≈øe Malefactors any further, it will not be unnece≈ø≈øary to make a little digre≈ø≈øion, and ≈øee what evidence the Righteous Providence of God doth Admini≈øter towards a fuller detection of their Sin and Guilt.

Mi≈øtris Weeks being decea≈øed, and Doctor Holland a Phy≈øitian of the Town having averred it to be by Poy≈øon; the Coronor was ≈øent for, to inquire into the cau≈øes of her death; who having impannel'd his
Jury, and examined Witne≈ø≈øes, do all Unanimou≈øly concurre in their Verdict, that ≈øhe was murdered, and that by Poy≈øon.

The ≈øame Verdict al≈øo was given in by another Jury, that ≈øate upon the death of Mi≈øtris Pengelley. The ob≈øtinacy of the Nur≈øe to the very in≈øtant of her going off the Ladder, in denying her ≈øelf either principal or acce≈ø≈øary to this bloody fact, will excu≈øe the relator, if he ≈øubjoyn the re≈øpective depo≈øitions of ≈øeveral Witne≈ø≈øes upon their Oath concerning it, that ≈øo the Ju≈øtice of God may be glorified, and no Sini≈øter thoughts of the Judge, Grand or Petty Juries that condemned her be entertained.

div.head: The Examination of Chri≈øtopher Scibbow of Plymouth in the County of Devon Dyer, had and taken at Plymouth afore≈øaid, by and before Thomas Payne Gentleman, Coronor for our Soveraign Lord the King, within the Liberty of the Burrough of Plymouth afore≈øaid, on the Corporal Oath of the ≈øaid Examinant, this 27th. day of Augu≈øt, Anno Domini, 1675.
div.p: THe ≈øaid Examinant ≈øaith, that on Wedne≈øday night la≈øt, he was at the Pri≈øon window in Plymouth, where Anne Evans Spin≈øter was committed on Su≈øpition, for poy≈øoning Elizabeth the wife of William Weeks Dyer, when and where this Examinant heard the ≈øaid Anne Evans to ≈øay, that the Nur≈øe (meaning Philip the wife of Richard Cary) did ask of her about a month before to buy ≈øome Rats-bane, and that ≈øhe gave an≈øwer to the ≈øaid Nur≈øe, that ≈øhe would not do it, becau≈øe the Apothecary would put her name upon the Book.

div.head: The Examination of Su≈øanna, the Wife of Brian Can≈øfield of Plymouth afore≈øaid Planter, taken before the ≈øaid Coronor, on the Corporal Oath of the ≈øaid Examinant, the day and year afore≈øaid.
div.p: THe ≈øaid Examinant ≈øaith, that on Munday la≈øt; ≈øhe went and ≈øaw Elizabeth, the Wife of William Weeks Dyer, and found her very Sick, and this Examinant, and other Per≈øons that were pre≈øent, did believe that ≈øhe had been poy≈øoned, upon which there was ≈øome new Broth made, and made with ≈øome of the ≈øameOatmeal. Girts, that had been put into the old Broth, and when it was made, ≈øhe gave it to a great Dog, who pre≈øently Vomited it up again. She al≈øo ≈øaith, that Anne Evans, Ma≈øter Weeks his Servant, ≈øhewed this Examinant the bottom of the new Broth, where was ≈øound a Yellow Gravel, and one ≈øhewing of it to Mi≈øtris Hurd and others, they did believe that it was Rats-bane.

div.head: The Examination of Alice, the Wife of Anthony Windeit of Plymouth, afore≈øaid Clothier, taken as afore≈øaid before the ≈øaid Coronor on her Oath.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid Examinant ≈øaith, that on Wedne≈øday la≈øt, ≈øhe went and ≈øaw Ma≈øter William Weeks Dyer, and Mary Pengelley, being very Sick, it being reported that they and Mi≈øtris Weeks had been poy≈øoned, on which it was ≈øaid, that theOatmeal. Girts which were in the hou≈øe and had not been u≈øed, ≈øhould be wa≈øhed, and the ≈øame were accordingly wa≈øhed by Anne Evans, the ≈øaid Ma≈øter Weeks
his Servant, and in the bottom there was found ≈øome Yellow, like Gravel, part whereof was about the bigne≈øs of a ≈ømall Pins head, upon which this Examinant blamed the ≈øaid Anne Evans for wa≈øhing the ≈øame without order, who confe≈ø≈øed that ≈øhe had done it without Order.

div.head: The Examination and Information of Mary Pengelley of Plymouth, in the County of Devon Widow, taken before the ≈øaid Coronor on her Corporal Oath, the thirtieth day of Augu≈øt, Anno Domini 1675.
div.p:
THe ≈øaid Examinant ≈øaith, that ye≈øterday la≈øt was Sevennight in the Morning, Anne Evans the Apprentice of Ma≈øter William Weeks Dyer, fetched a Tankard of Strong Beer, on which there ≈øeemed unto this Examinant that there was Keam, for which ≈øhe was blamed, of which this Examinant drank hearty: And now this Examinant doth verily believe by what hath happened ≈øince, that that which ≈øhe took to be Keam on the ≈øaid Beer, was Poy≈øon: And this Examinant further ≈øaith, that afterwards ye≈øterday was Sevennight ≈øhe being come down over the Staires in the Kitchin, about Noon the ≈øaid Anne Evans asked this Examinant if ≈øhe would eat any Pottage, (the ≈øaid William Weeks and Elizabeth his Wife, this Examinants Father and Mother having eaten Pottage a little before,) and this Examinant told her that ≈øhe would, and accordingly ≈øhe did eat a Di≈øh of Pottage, (being out of the ≈øame Di≈øh that her ≈øaid Father and Mother did ≈øo eat Pottage a little before,) and that pre≈øently after this Examinant and her ≈øaid Father and Mother were taken exceeding Sick, of which her ≈øaid Mother died the next day after. THe Witne≈ø≈øes having been Examined, their Depo≈øitions taken, they are all bound over to Pro≈øecute our Malefactors at the next A≈ø≈øizes for the County of Devon, who≈øe Mittimus is now Signed and Sealed, and they ≈øent to the High Goal near the Ca≈øtle of Exon.
